user: What is CS 190? Is it hard? Are there pre-reqs?
bot:
I searched for the course CS 190 and found the following details:

- **Title**: Software Design Studio
- **Description**: This course teaches the art of software design: how to decompose large complex systems into classes that can be implemented and maintained easily. Topics include the causes of complexity, modular design, techniques for creating deep classes, minimizing the complexity associated with exceptions, in-code documentation, and name selection. The class involves significant system software implementation and uses an iterative approach consisting of implementation, review, and revision. The course is taught in a studio format with in-class discussions and code reviews in addition to lectures. Prerequisite: CS 140 or equivalent. Apply at: [Course Application Link](https://web.stanford.edu/class/cs190).

Regarding whether CS 190 is hard, I found the following information:

- **Average Hours Spent**: 19.29 hours per week.
- **Summary of Reviews**: The course receives positive reviews and recommendations. Students mention that it significantly enhances their skills as engineers, especially in software design and coding practices. While it requires a substantial commitment of time and effort, the rewards include a deeper understanding of coding principles and improved design skills. Overall, it is highly recommended for anyone interested in software engineering.

As for prerequisites, CS 190 requires the completion of CS 140 or an equivalent course. 

Could you please provide me with the details of the courses you want to take?

user: Does it have to be letter for the coterm, or can it count with credit/no credit?
bot: For the coterm program, CS 224R must be taken for a letter grade. This course is listed as one of the courses that satisfy the Significant Implementation Requirement, which must be taken for a letter grade.
turn_context:
answer = answer('Does CS 224R need to be taken for a letter grade for the coterm program, or can it be taken as Credit/No Credit?')
answer.result = [{'sheet_requirements': 'DEPARTMENT OF COMPUTER SCIENCEnMSCS Program Sheet (2023-24)nnGENERAL INSTRUCTIONS: Before the end of your first quarter, complete a program sheet by filling in the number, name and units  of each course you intend to take for your degree. Program sheets, as well as foundation course waiver forms, may be submitted  electronically on the Gates Information Network at http://gin.stanford.edu/ using your CS ID and password (click on the ‘Dashboard’ link). See http://cs.stanford.edu/degrees/mscs/programsheets/psguide2324.pdf for detailed instructions. nnFOUNDATIONS REQUIREMENT: You must satisfy the requirements listed in each of the following areas; all courses taken elsewhere  must be approved by your advisor via the foundation course waiver form. Do not enter anything in the “Units” column for courses  taken elsewhere or for Stanford courses counted towards your undergraduate degree. nnLogic, Automata & Complexity: CS103nProbability: CS109, Stat116, CME106, MS&E220,  or EE178nAlgorithmic Analysis: CS161nComputer Organ & Sys: CS107 or 107EnPrinciples of Computer Systems: CS111nnTOTAL UNITS USED TO SATISFY FOUNDATIONS REQUIREMENT (May not exceed 10 units.) nnSIGNIFICANT IMPLEMENTATION REQUIREMENT: At least one course in your MS program should be designated as satisfying the  Significant Implementation Requirement. Note that this course will also be used to satisfy some other requirement (i.e., Depth, or  Elective). Must be taken for a letter grade,* must be taken at Stanford.
